awd_titl_txt: Travel: Student Support for the 38th International Conference on Logic Programming in 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports student travel for select students participating in the Doctoral Consortium (DC) and All School on Logic Programming (FSLP) at the International Conference on Logic Programming (ICLP) that will be held in August 2022 in Haifa, Israel.  ICLP is the leading international conference for researchers in logic programming, an important subfield of artificial intelligence. This activity will bring together a broad community of researchers in this important field and supports junior researchers at this critical early-career stage.  

The DC creates the opportunity to bring in participants who might not have attended an AI conference due to lack of resources. This is especially true for those at smaller institutions and those which have less developed AI programs. Engaging such participants has the potential to draw more talent into AI research, improve research ideas in their formative stage, and engender collaborations across the breadth of disciplines.  This event provides students with invaluable exposure to outside perspectives on their work at a critical time in their research and enables them to explore their career objectives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The International Conference on Logic Programming 2023 (London, UK) has benefited greatly from the availability of funds. The grant was able to support a diverse group of students coming from five distinct US institutions:

  • Padalkar, Parth; University of Texas at Dallas

  • Temple, Nathan; University of Texas at Austin

  • Tummala, Vineel; Miami University

  • Portero, Eleuterio Juan Lillo  (Lute Lillo); University of Nebraska Omaha

  • Hansen, Zachary; University of Nebraska Omaha

  • Rajasekharan, Abhiramon; University of Texas at Dallas  

  • Kierans, Aidan; University of Connecticut

Each of these students provided a letter of support by their advisor clearly articulating the advantages which the grant money brings to the research endeavors of these students. All students but one were active participants at the conference having to present either at the main conference or affiliated workshops. The student who did not have a presentation at a conference was nevertheless engaged in Master thesis work pertaining logic programming. This student is currently starting a CS PhD program at the University of Vermont. All stated information clearly illustrates the immense value of the travel grants of the kind that enable students to participate in prominent scientific events engaging them with their research field at a new level and promoting their further engagements by joining research workforce of the country.


Last Modified: 01/02/2024
Modified by: Yuliya Lierler
